1.1  Introduction

Pacific Gas and Electric (PG&E) operates the Gateway Generating Station, a nominal 530 megawatt (MW) natural gas-fired combined cycle electric power generating facility located in Antioch, California.  The Gateway Generating Station uses aqueous ammonia to reduce the emissions of nitrogen oxides to the atmosphere.  As the company responsible for operating Gateway Generating Station, PG&E takes its safety obligations in storing and using ammonia seriously.  The following document describes what could happen if there were to be an accident, the steps we take every day to ensure a safely operating plant, and what to do in the event of an emergency.

1.2  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

PG&E?s vision is to be the leading utility in the United States and PG&E?s values are presented below:

We act with integrity and communicate honestly and openly. 
We are passionate about meeting our customers? needs and delivering for our shareholders.
We are accountable for all of our own actions; these include safety, protecting the environment and supporting our communities.
We work together as a team and are committed to excellence and innovation.
We respect each other and celebrate our diversity.

The Gateway Generating Station accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates proven technology, staff training on operation and maintenance practices, and tested management system practices.  All applicable procedures of the State of California and the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Prevention Program are adhered to, including key elements such as training, systems management, and emergency response procedures.  

As a supplier of energy to approximately five percent of Americans and more than 40 percent of Californians, we recognize that the choices we make about the way we produce and deliver our products and serve our customers can have a direct impact on the environment. We also b

licy forms the foundation for the programs PG&E uses to achieve this goal. This policy requires that employees do their jobs with the goal of creating a work and business environment free from injury, illness and property damage for the benefit of employees, customers and the general public; employees (1) perform work in a way that protects and promotes the safety and health of themselves, co-workers and the public, and (2) comply with all applicable health and safety laws and regulations; and each officer manages effectively the occupational and public safety and health matters concerning business activities for which he or she is responsible.

Gateway Generating Station staff verify and improve the safety and environmental program by implementing the Risk Management Plan (RMP) prevention program requirements such as performing hazard reviews, maintaining current operating procedures, conducting training on the ammonia system, conducting compliance audits, and implementing procedures for process modifications.  

This document complies with the EPA Risk Management Program under Section 112 ? of the Clean Air Act (CAA) Amendments of 1990, 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part 68, and the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program under California Code of Regulations (CCR) Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5.  This document summarizes our existing health and safety programs, our internal management response procedures, and ongoing actions that are designed to prevent or minimize impacts of accidental releases of ammonia to the environment.  Gateway Generating Station has prepared an emergency action plan to handle any potential accidental releases.

1.3  Facility Description and Regulated Substances Information

Gateway Generating Station is located on Wilbur Avenue, one mile northeast of the City of Antioch, in Contra Costa County, California, on the southern shore of the San Joaquin River. Highway 4 and the Antioch Bridge are just east of the site.

Immediately south and west of the site are existing industrial facilities. The river borders the north side, while a recreational marina, open space and additional industrial land uses occur east of the site.  

The Gateway Generating Station combined cycle power unit consists of two natural gas-fired combustion turbine generators, two heat recovery steam generators (HRSGs), and one steam turbine generator. In the combined cycle process, electricity is generated from the combustion turbines and the steam turbine. Each combustion turbine generator converts the thermal energy of the natural gas fuel to mechanical energy, which drives the electrical generator. At the same time, the thermal energy from the exhaust flue gas off the combustion turbines is directed to the HRSGs to convert pressurized water into steam, which turns the steam turbine to drive the electricity generator. The facility also include two 195-foot tall exhaust stacks on the heat recovery steam generators, one air cool condenser system, a wet surface air cooler, an inlet chiller system, storage tanks, a control building, electrical power transformers, and transmission facilities to interconnect the generated electricity to the power grid. 

Aqueous ammonia is used at PG&E?s Gateway Generating Station in the plant?s selective catalytic reduction (SCR) system to reduce Nox emissions.  Up to 18,020 gallons of aqueous ammonia solution (39,681 lbs of ammonia in solution) may be present in the process at any time.  

The maximum quantity of aqueous ammonia stored at Gateway Generating Station exceeds the federal RMP and CalARP specified threshold quantities of 20,000 pounds and 500 pounds, respectively; thus, the facility is subject to federal RMP and CalARP regulations.  The aqueous ammonia process is a Program 2 process.

1.4  Summary of the Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps 

Management System

RMP regulations require those facilities with processes subject to

Programs 2 or 3 to develop a management system to oversee the implementation of the program elements.  The management system has to be assigned to a qualified person or position that has the overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the RMP.  PG&E has assigned the Plant Manager as the qualified person who has the overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the RMP.  The Plant Manager is assisted by the Operations Supervisor, Plant Engineer, and the Maintenance Supervisor in the implementation of the RMP.  

The RMP and changes to it are communicated by supervisors to staff through normal day to day interaction, refresher training, regular safety meetings, and the management of change procedures outlined in the prevention program.

The management system activities are further discussed below:

Planning ? Gateway Generating Station has an environmental, health, and safety policy that clearly defines PG&E?s goals and obligations.

Organizing ? The Plant Manager is responsible for ensuring that written prevention procedures are in place and implements as described in the prevention program document.

Implementing ? The Plant Manager is responsible for implementing the Risk Management Program at Gateway Generating Station.  The Plant Engineer is responsible for arranging for and tracking training of staff. 

Controlling ? The Plant Engineer is responsible for conducting the internal compliance audits of the prevention program to ensure the procedures are being implemented by staff.  Unless otherwise indicated, RMP records are maintained for five years. 

Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The prevention program elements described in the following section represent integrated administrative controls intended to ensure the safety of workers, the public, and the environment.  The program elements such as hazard reviews, compliance audits, and incident investigation result in the development of additio

nal safeguards.  In addition, this facility is staffed 24 hours per day, 365 days per year.  Some of the safety features of the ammonia process are described below.

Aqueous Ammonia Process

The aqueous ammonia storage tanks are enclosed within a walled containment basin that slopes to a centrally located, covered sump beneath the tanks that runs the length of the containment area. There is a walled containment pad under the tanker truck unloading facility that drains into the covered sump under the tanks.

Standby power needed for electrical systems such as monitors and alarms is provided by the Uninterruptible Power Supply System. Other safety features of the aqueous ammonia storage and unloading facility include:

Ammonia area monitoring system with audible and visible alarms
Eyewash and shower station
Piping and connections for washdown of containment basin with clean water
Permanent lighting
Lightning protection
Truck barrier posts to protect ammonia tanks and delivery lines
Liquid level indication and high-level alarm for each tank, easily visible from the unloading position
Tank level and pressure indicators and pressure relief valves and alarms in the plant control room.
Shut-off valves located on the tank fill lines which close automatically if the emergency high-level alarm is triggered
Local manual controls for all pumps
Vacuum breaker valves on each tank
Safety equipment (for two personnel) including: two full face respiratory devices, two sets of escape respirators, non-vented chemical goggles, two pairs of ammonia-resistant gloves, two pairs of ammonia-resistant hoods, two pairs of ammonia-resistant pants and jacket/slicker, one first aid kit, and one fire extinguisher.
Area sensors are located in the ammonia unloading and storage facility and injection skid to monitor for ambient ammonia concentrations. Alarms are designed to annunciate in the control room with local audible alarms for ammonia releases at the facilities.

Prevention Program Elements

The Gateway Generating Station accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements:

Detailed management system and clear levels of responsibilities and team member roles
Comprehensive safety process information that is readily available to staff, emergency responders, and contractors
Comprehensive preventive maintenance program
A hazard review with operation and maintenance staff participation
Use of state-of-the-art process and safety equipment
Use of accurate and effective operating procedures, written with operations and maintenance staff participation
High level of training of operators and maintenance staff
Implementation of an incident investigation, inspection, and auditing program using qualified staff

For the aqueous ammonia process, the prevention program contains the following elements.  

Safety Information
Hazard Review
Operating Procedures
Training Program
Maintenance
Compliance Audits
Incident Investigation

1.5  Five-Year Accident History Summary

EPA RMP regulations require reporting the five-year accident history of the covered processes.  The details of accidental releases are required for accidents that have caused at least one of the following:

Onsite deaths, injuries, or significant property damage
Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place

Gateway Generating Station is a new facility and has had no accidents involving ammonia.

1.6  Emergency Response Program Summary

Gateway Generating Station has established a written emergency action program that is followed by the employees to help safely control accidental releases of hazardous substances.  RMP regulations require that an Emergency Action Plan be prepared for facilities that are not responding facilities.  The plan must be prepared in accordance with the provisions of 29 CFR 1910.38, Emergency Action Plan.  The Emergency Action Plan described in this section is for facilities whose employees are n

ot responders to emergency situations. This program has been coordinated (reviewed) by the CCCHSD and the Contra Costa County Fire Protection District, which are members of the Local Emergency Response Planning Committee (LEPC).  Emergency operation and action procedures are also reviewed once per year. 

The CCCHSD Incident Response Team is the designated primary response agency for Gateway Generating Station.  PG&E has coordinated response actions with response agencies by the following activities:

Submitting the Hazardous Materials Business Plan/ Facility Environmental Emergency Plan to the CCCHSD Hazardous Materials Program on December 28, 2006 (Original Plan) and June 15, 2007 (Revised Plan). 

Submitting copy of the Hazardous Materials Business Plan/Facility Environmental Emergency Plan and Title 22 (CCR) Hazardous Waste Contingency Plan Agreement between PG&E  and Local Emergency Response Organization to the Contra Costa County Fire Protection District (October, 22, 2007), Contra Costa County Sheriff's Department (October 22, 2007), and Sutter Delta Medical Center (October 22, 2007). These agencies were also invited to visit and familiarize the facility.

Conducting the hazard review on the aqueous ammonia system on December 13, 2007 with CCCHSD staff

Coordinate site emergency response training with identified first responders

Reviewing the Contra Costa County Hazardous Materials Area Plan and providing comment, as appropriate

1.7  Planned Changes to Improve Safety

A number of studies and inspections have been conducted or will soon be conducted to improve the safety of the ammonia process at Gateway Generating Station. The hazard review of the aqueous ammonia process was conducted in December 2007 and a seismic assessment of the aqueous ammonia process was completed completed in October in 2008.  

During these studies and inspections, several additional risk reduction measures were recommended to improve safety at Gateway Generating Station.  The risk
reduction measures include confirming vendor procedures, confirming maintenance procedures, and considering adding alarms.
